Expectation1: Take scheduled breaks and adhere to work hours
Situation1: The call volume is light, and supervisors allow flexible timing for breaks.
Situation2: Savings are set aside and friends are going this season.
Story: I sit at my desk, headset resting around my neck, watching the call queue dwindle to almost nothing. The office is unusually quiet, and my supervisor has just announced that we can take our breaks whenever we want today. I glance at the clock, thinking about how I could use this time to research flights and finalize my Hajj plans. My friends are all set to go this season, and I’ve been saving for years, waiting for the right moment. But as a telemarketer, I’m expected to stick to my scheduled hours, even if today’s flexibility is a rare gift. I feel the weight of both roles pressing on me—my job expects me to be present and reliable, while my faith calls me to fulfill a lifelong dream and religious duty. My heart races as I hover over the “break” button, torn between seizing this chance for Hajj preparations and staying true to my work commitments. The tension inside me grows, and I can’t help but wonder which expectation I should honor in this moment.
